posts.name: Alperen Atikebaş
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone. We are planning to build a test chassis to improve ourselves in the off-season. There will not be any system on robot. We are going to make a belly pan for the first time. And our technical knowledge on this subject is not enough. I would like you to comment on the robot CAD in general. Especially, we could not decide where to place the connector of the battery cable. How can we get the battery cables to the main breaker and PDH . I am leaving the Onshape CAD link of the robot below. I would appreciate your help in this regard.

Ekran görüntüsü 2025-04-12 160926 1274×1275 104 KB

Ekran görüntüsü 2025-04-12 160926 1274×1275 104 KB

Ekran görüntüsü 2025-04-12 160926 1274×1275 104 KB

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
Based on what we did last year…we did a test mule (Milk Crate) of the base as well.  It was our first time with swerve.

We added everything that would be necessary to operate the base…and only the base.  from the looks of your base CAD…you need to add controllers (looks like you are running NEOs), and an IMU.  This would be the minimum to run it prior to code.

IF the Roborio is in the middle…put the IMU on top of it.

Running wire to the PDH and the Breaker should be easy on where you have it currently.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
And after looking at the belly pan a bit more…the arcs at the corners could be a bit closer to the wheels.  Your base is about 27X27"…you may need more real estate for other items in the future.  It is always good to plan for that.  Another thing to consider is watching this video.  I am not saying your design is bad…it is actually very good.

This would help you as you go into the swerve.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Alperen Atikebaş
posts.cooked:
First of all, thank you for your answer.

Yes, we use NEO V1.1 Brushless Motors in our robot and we use Spark Max as a motor controller. And, we use a very functional 3D printing bracket to fix Spark Maxes and avoid cable mess. I leave the photo below.

Ekran görüntüsü 2025-04-12 232410 1131×1090 153 KB

Ekran görüntüsü 2025-04-12 232410 1131×1090 153 KB

Ekran görüntüsü 2025-04-12 232410 1131×1090 153 KB

We also use NavX2 as IMU. As you said, Roborio is in the middle and IMU is on it.

As for the Belly Pan surface area, we do not need much surface area on this chassis, this is quite enough. This chassis will always be a test chassis for the development of the software and stabilisation of the robot and no different system will be placed on it.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: It depends what you’re after here…. But I’d recommend keeping it solid so that you have a heavier chassis which will be more representative of an actual robot for programmers and drivers, but less good experience for making a belly pan for your build crew. Just a thought! You could also add weights!

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: I’d suggest dropping the frame, like many 2024 robots, including this one .
From a purely programming viewpoint I would suggest adding  some sort of vision system if you can. Being able to run vision localization on our test chassis was a huge blessing this offseason.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: In terms of frame size one thing you might want to consider is setting your frame size before the season starts. We did that for the first time this year and it majorly sped up our early robot progress. We set our size to 27.5" x 27.5" and that worked out well for us this year. But depending on your robot architecture that might not be feasible. (ie; 359 needing a long robot for the pink arm) The main benefit of doing this is you can start assembly and wiring of your robot chassis before design is done. And the same goes with bumper construction.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Tanmay Darji
posts.cooked: for the belly pan I would recommend doing something like a pegboard with holes at some standard distance and some tap size (our chassis this yr has 10-32 tap holes every inch)  for future mounting that you may need to do

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Picking up on the above, an 0.201” hole can be a 10-32 clearance or a 1/4-20 tap hole.
